places.name: Africa
places.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

persons.name: DiodorusSiculus
persons.description: Of Sicily was an ancient Greek historian. He is known for writing the monumental universal history Bibliotheca historica, in forty books, fifteen of which survive intact, between 60 and 30 BCE.

persons.name: JesusChrist
persons.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

persons.name: Jupiter
persons.description: Also known as Jove. The god of the sky and thunder, and king of the gods in ancient Roman religion and mythology.

persons.name: FrancisWilford
persons.description: Indologist, Orientalist, member of the Asiatic Society of Bengal, and constant contributor to its journal, Asiatic Researches, for which he wrote a number of unreliable articles on ancient Hindu geography, mythography and other subjects.

works.name: Asiatick Researches, Or, Transactions of the Society Instituted in Bengal, for Inquiring Into the History and Antiquities, the Arts, Sciences, and Literature of Asia

persons.name: Amenophis
persons.description: Also known as Akhenaten, Egyptian pharaoh who radically reformed Egyptian religion.

persons.name: Sesostris
persons.description: Also spelled Sesoösis or Sesonchosis, was a legendary king of ancient Egypt who, according to Herodotus, led a military expedition into parts of Europe.

persons.name: FlaviusJosephus
persons.description: Roman-Jewish historian and military leader.

persons.name: Manetho
persons.description: Egyptian priest, from Sebennytos, who lived in the Ptolemaic Kingdom during the Hellenistic period. He wrote the Aegyptiaca (History of Egypt) in Greek, a major chronological source for the reigns of the kings of ancient Egypt.

persons.name: Herodotus
persons.description: Greek historian and geographer who wrote a detailed account of the Greco-Persian Wars - one the earliest existing historical texts.

places.name: Libya
places.description: Libya, officially the State of Libya, is a country in the Maghreb region of North Africa.

places.name: Red Sea
places.description: A seawater inlet of the Indian Ocean, lying between Africa and Asia.

places.name: Ganges
places.description: The Ganges is a river in Asia running through India and Bangladesh. It is part of the third largest river on earth.

persons.name: JohnBentley
persons.description: Member of the Asiatic Society in Calcutta who wrote on Hindu astronomy.

persons.name: Jean SylvainBailly
persons.description: French astronomer, mathematician, and political leader of the early part of the French Revolution.

persons.name: Plato
persons.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

places.name: Lake Baikal
places.description: Lake Baikal is an ancient, massive lake in the mountainous Russian region of Siberia, north of the Mongolian border. Considered the deepest lake in the world, it’s circled by a network of hiking paths called the Great Baikal Trail.

persons.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
persons.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Lake Baikal
places.description: Lake Baikal is an ancient, massive lake in the mountainous Russian region of Siberia, north of the Mongolian border. Considered the deepest lake in the world, it’s circled by a network of hiking paths called the Great Baikal Trail.

persons.name: Pierre-SimonLaplace
persons.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
persons.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jean SylvainBailly
persons.description: French astronomer, mathematician, and political leader of the early part of the French Revolution.

persons.name: Jean SylvainBailly
persons.description: French astronomer, mathematician, and political leader of the early part of the French Revolution.

places.name: Sais, Egypt
places.description: An ancient Egyptian city in the Western Nile Delta. On its ruins today stands the town of Sa el-Hagar or Sa El Hajar.

places.name: Babylon
places.description: An ancient city located on the lower Euphrates river in southern Mesopotamia, within modern-day Iraq.

places.name: Memphis
places.description: The ancient capital of Inebu-hedj, the first nome of Lower Egypt. Its ruins are located in the vicinity of the present-day village of Mit Rahina.

persons.name: Jupiter
persons.description: Also known as Jove. The god of the sky and thunder, and king of the gods in ancient Roman religion and mythology.

persons.name: DiodorusSiculus
persons.description: Of Sicily was an ancient Greek historian. He is known for writing the monumental universal history Bibliotheca historica, in forty books, fifteen of which survive intact, between 60 and 30 BCE.

persons.name: WilliamWordsworth
persons.description: English poet who, with Samuel Taylor Coleridge, published Lyrical Ballads. Davy contributed to seeing the second edition (1800) through the press in Bristol. Poet Laureate from 1843.

persons.name: JuliusCaesar
persons.description: Roman general and dictator who first landed an army in Britain. Assassinated to prevent him gaining total power in Rome.

persons.name: JesusChrist
persons.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

persons.name: Pythagoras
persons.description: Pythagoras of Samos was an ancient Ionian Greek philosopher, polymath, and the eponymous founder of Pythagoreanism. Believed in the primacy of number.

persons.name: Pythagoras
persons.description: Pythagoras of Samos was an ancient Ionian Greek philosopher, polymath, and the eponymous founder of Pythagoreanism. Believed in the primacy of number.

works.name: Discourse the Eleventh, on the Philosophy of the Asiaticks
works.author: William Jones

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

places.name: Balkh
places.description: Balkh is a town in the Balkh Province of Afghanistan.

places.name: Samarkand
places.description: Samarkand, or Samarqand, is a city in south-eastern Uzbekistan and among the oldest continuously inhabited cities in Central Asia.

persons.name: Jean Joseph MarieAmiot
persons.description: French Jesuit priest, who worked in Qing China, during the reign of the Qianlong Emperor.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: ChinYen
persons.description: Unidentified.

persons.name: Jean Joseph MarieAmiot
persons.description: French Jesuit priest, who worked in Qing China, during the reign of the Qianlong Emperor.

persons.name: Chin ChiHoang
persons.description: Now transliterated as Qin Shi Huang Di, the first Chinese emperor.

persons.name: JesusChrist
persons.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

places.name: Chaldea
places.description: A small country that existed between the late 10th or early 9th and mid-6th centuries BC, after which the country and its people were absorbed and assimilated into the indigenous population of Babylonia.

places.name: Pekin
places.description: A historic spelling of a name of Beijing, the capital of China.
